titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the KUHT Film and Video
titlestmt.author: Samantha Herber, Hannah Walker, Shyam Patel, Saadia Mohamed, Toshia Miracle

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was encoded in EAD by Archon 3.21 from an SQL database source on October 18th, 2016.

titlepage.titleproper: Guide to the KUHT Film and Video 1950/2000

did.head: Overview of the Collection

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

did.abstract: The KUHT Collection includes film reels, videotapes, correspondence, memoranda, publications, clippings, photographs, and related material dating from the 1950s through the 1990s. The bulk of the material dates from the mid-1960s to 1990s with a few photographs dating to the early to mid-1950s.

bioghist.head: Historical Note:
bioghist.p: KUHT-TV debuted on May 25, 1953, as America's first educational television station. Since then it has served as a model for other educational television stations. Its main goal is to provide quality programming to students, faculty, and the entire community. KUHT predates the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) and the Public Broadcasting System (PBS). Its history includes award-winning local and national productions, including a national Emmy Award for excellence. KUHT is licensed to the University of Houston, and is located in the LeRoy and Lucile Melcher Center for Public Broadcasting located at 4343 Elgin, on the northeast corner of the main campus.

controlaccess.head: Access Terms
controlaccess.p: This Collection is indexed under the following controlled access subject terms.

accruals.head: Accruals:
accruals.p: Additional unprocessed boxes arrived in September 2015.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use:
userestrict.p: Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, but copyright normally belongs to the creator of the materials or their heirs. The researcher has full responsibility for determining copyright status, locating copyright holders, and abiding by current copyright laws when publishing or displaying copies of Special Collections material in print or electronic form. For more information, consult the appropriate librarian.
Some collection materials may be restricted for reasons of intellectual property, privacy, or confidentiality.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Information of acquisition method not available.

altformavail.head: Digital Collections:
altformavail.p: KUHT Film and Video in the UH Libraries Audio/Video Repository (https://av.lib.uh.edu/?f%5Bcollection_ssim%5D%5B%5D=KUHT+Film+and+Video)

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: KUHT Film and Video. Courtesy of Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The KUHT Collection includes film reels, videotapes, correspondence, memoranda, publications, clippings, photographs, and related material dating from the 1950s through the 1990s. The bulk of the material dates from the mid-1960s to 1990s with a few photographs dating to the early to mid-1950s.
Please contact the collection curator Emily Vinson (evinson@uh.edu) for further information regarding all film and video material.

The series in the Collection include: Discrepancy Files, Development and Production Files by Jim Fisher and Paul Yeager, Gulf Region Education Television Affiliates (GRETA), Photographs, Ephemera, and Awards.

Visit the University of Houston Libraries Audio/Video Repository to access more than 750 videos from the KUHT Collection. Digitization and access for these items was made possible by grants from the U.S. Institute of Museum and Library Services and Texas State Library and Archives Commission (2017) and Recordings at Risk from the Council on Library and Information Resources (CLIR) made possible by funding from The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation (2019).

People are Taught to be Different

scopecontent.p: Funded by National Educational Television, People Are Taught to be Different was a 12-part series written and produced by Texas Southern University sociology professor Dr. Henry Allen Bullock, and performed by TSU students. This series was an anthropological study on black life based around the “idea that racial discrimination has to be literally taught, that people are not naturally prejudiced.”
